summary.seg: This manuscript is a Miscellany of Greek texts copied by Henri II Estienne, Henry Scrimgeour, and Patrick Young. The manuscript is probably a composite, formed of various parts which were originally independent and were copied at different times. However, since it is now not possible to ascertain the quire structure, and to distinguish, for instance, different kinds of paper, it is described here as a whole.

Trinity MS O.5.23 is described in James' catalogue as containing H. Scrimger's Collections: this is, however, a limited description of this codex. Only a few leaves can be assigned to Scrimgeour (or Scrimger, 1505?-1572), ff. 66r-68v, where the Scottish diplomat and book collector copied an extract from Photius' Bibliotheca about Helladius.

Besides this, the volume contains transcriptions and notes made by another important figure in the 16th-century scholarly milieu: the French printer and classical scholar Henri II Estienne (Henricus Stephanus, 1531-1598). By his hand are written, for example, a series of transcriptions and notes on Lucian. Occasionally he indicated his exemplars: there are a codex Abbatiae (see f. 27v), a codex Scipionis quod fuit Argyropyli (see f. 15r), and a codex D. Marci quod fuit Georgii Anto. Vespucii (see f. 32r: on the basis of the content, of the ownership by the convent of S Marco and by Giorgio Antonio Vespucci, this codex could be Florence, Biblioteca Medicea Laurenziana, Plut. 57.13).

Other texts were written later, by the great-nephew of Scrimgeour, Patrick Young (or Junius, 1584-1652); among them on ff. 74v-75v he copied four inscriptions, one was on a stone originally in St James's Park, Westminster, and is now lost; another is an epitaph of his father Peter Young, who died in 1628.

msItem.title: Transcriptions and notes on Lucian
msItem.incipit: f. 2r Σαμοσατεὺς· οὕτως· ἐν τῷ πῶς δεῖ ἱστορίαν
msItem.note: On f. 2r there is a note on the text, saying that Scrimgeour copied the extracts from various manuscripts and a printed book in Florence: H. Scrimgerus haec aliunde descripsit ex codicibus Abbatiae cuiusdam, Florentino impresso, Scipionis qui fuit Arguropyli, D. Marci G. Vespucii; the text, however, was copied almost entirely by Henry II Estienne (see Hands)
From f. 4v, where another scribe (Henry Estienne) copied the text, there are also translations of words and expressions in Latin, notes and scholia
Ff. 41r-41v are blank

msItem.title: Oneirocriticon
msItem.incipit: f. 42r Βασιλεῖ προσλαλῶν τις ἄπρακτος μένει· βαιλεύς
msItem.explicit: f. 43v ὕδωρ πίνων πηλῶδες, ἐν λύπαις ἔσῃ
msItem.note: On f. 42r, in the left margin, there is a note in black ink by another hand (probably Patrick Young) about the text: Edita sunt haec ἀλφαβητικῶς sub nomine Astrampsychi : the text however does not correspond to Astrampsychus' Oneirocriticon as printed in Artemidori Daldiani et Achmetis Sereimi F. Oneirocritica. Astrampsychi et Nicephori versus etiam Oneirocritici. Nicolai Rigaltii ad Artemidorum Notae, Paris 1603

The text is organised in brief phrases, the subjects are written in red in the margin, and they are arranged alphabetically; a few phrases correspond, with some differences, to F. Drexl, 'Das Traumbuch des Patriarchen Germanos', in: Λαογραφία 7 (1923), pp. 433-448

msItem.title: Variae lectiones in Lucianum
msItem.incipit: f. 44r Περὶ τοῦ ἐνυπνίου ἤτοι βίος Λουκιάνου
msItem.note: ff. 45r-49r are blank

msItem.title: Transcription of three inscriptions
msItem.note: In the manuscript, the text of the inscription has been transcribed without breathings and accents
The text has been written perpendicular to the normal direction of the script
ff. 51v-56v are blank

msItem.title: Decree of demos (of Smyrna) concerning sympoliteia with Magnesia (Sip.) and relations with King Seleukos (II), 245/243? BC; probably from Smyrna
msItem.incipit: f. 49v Ἔδοξεν τῷ δήμῳ στρατηγῶν γνώμῃ ἐπειδὴ πρότερον τε καθ’ ὃν καιρὸν βασιλεὺς Σέλευκος
msItem.explicit: f. 50r l. 6 Διονύσιος Διονυτᾶ, Παρμενίσκος Πυθέου
msItem.note: CIG 3137, ll. 1-33; Hicks 176.I; Syll41 171, ll. 1-33; Michel 19, ll. 1-33; OGIS 229.I; Schmitt, Staatsverträge III 492.I (PH); IMag. Sip. 1.I (PH); *ISmyrna 573.I + II 2 p. 376

msItem.title: Treaty of sympoliteia between Smyrna and Magnesia (Sip.), with oaths; 245/243? BC; probably from Smyrna
msItem.incipit: f. 50r l. 7 Ἐπὶ ἱερέως Ἡγησίου, στεφανηφόρου δὲ Πυθοδώρου μηνὸς Ληναιῶνος ἀγαθῇ τύχῃ
msItem.explicit: f. 50v l. 30 ταῦτα δὲ ἀμφοτέροις τοῖς πλήθεσιν συντετελέσθαι τύχῃ ἀγαθῇ
msItem.note: CIG 3137, ll. 34-88; Hicks 176.II; Syll41 171, ll. 34-88; Michel 19, ll. 34-88; OGIS 229.II; Schmitt, Staatsverträge III 492.II; IMag. Sip. 1.II (PH); *ISmyrna 573.II + II 2 p. 376

msItem.title: Decree of demos (of Smyrna) including Palaimagnesia in sympoliteia between (Smyrna) and Magnesia (Sip.); 245/243? BC; probably from Smyrna
msItem.incipit: f. 50v l. 31 Ἔδοξεν τῷ δήμῳ στρατηγῶν γνώμῃ ἐπειδὴ προνοῶν ὁ δῆμος ὑπὲρ ἁπάντων τῶν τοῦ βασιλέως Σελεύκου συμφερόντων
msItem.explicit: f. 51r ἀναγέγραφθαι δὲ αὐτὸ καὶ ἐν τοῖς δημοσίοις
msItem.note: CIG 3137, ll. 89-108; Hicks 176.III; Syll41 171, ll. 89-108; Michel 19.III; OGIS 229.III; Schmitt, Staatsverträge III 492.III; IMag. Sip. 1.III (PH); *ISmyrna 573.III + II 2 p. 376

msItem.title: Τranscriptions, critical notes and variants to works by Isocrates, Aristotle ad Euripides
msItem.note:
The collection comprises
hypotheseis of Isocrates' Against the Sophists, Plataicus and Areopagiticus
critical notes and variants on Isocrates' To Philip, Archidamus, Busiris, Plataicus, Areopagiticus, Panathenaicus, To Philip, Archidamus, The team of horses
critical notes and variants to Aristotle' s Politics, and On plants
critical notes and variants to Euripides' Hecuba, Orestes, Phoenician Women, Hippolytus, Medea, Alcestis, Andromache, Suppliant Women, Iphigenia at Aulis, Iphigenia among the Taurians, Rhesus, Trojan Women, Bacchae, Children of Heracles, Helen, Ion
ff. 64v-65r are blank

msItem.title: Extract from the Bibliotheca
msItem.rubric: f. 66r Κατὰ τὴν ἐπιτομήν τινα ἐκ τῶν Διονυσίου τοῦ ἀττικίστου
msItem.incipit: f. 66r Ὅτι Διονύσιός φησι μὴ λέγειν τοὺς Ἀττικιστὰς ὠνησάμην
msItem.explicit: f. 68r αἰτίαν δὲ πρότερον ἔχοντα φόνου
msItem.note: The text, presented in the manuscript as a summary from Aelius Dionysius (active 2nd century) Dionysius, Aelius, active 2nd century , is an extract from cod. 279 of the Bibliotheca by patriarch Photius: R. Henry, Photius. Bibliothèque, Paris , pp. 170 l. 29-185 l. 30 (529b l. 29-535a l. 30); cod. 279 is dedicated to Helladius, hence a note by a later hand in the left margin, upper part, of f. 66r, Helladius v. Photium
msItem.filiation: These leaves were copied from MS Trinity O.1.5 ( Diller 1965 p. 395; see also Isepy 2020, p. 208 and note 98)
msItem.note: ff. 41r-41v are blank

msItem.title: Glossae in Herodotum
msItem.rubric: f. 69r Λεξικὸν τῶν Ἡροδοτείων λέξεων ἐκ μέρους κατὰ στοιχεῖον
msItem.incipit: f. 69r Ἀνέλῃ χρήσῃ, Ἀναξυρίδας. τὰ βαθέα καὶ βασιλικὰ τῶν ὑποδημάτων
msItem.explicit: f. 70r Ψῆνες· κωνώπια τὰ ἐν τοῖς ὀλύνθοις τοῖς ἄρσεσι
msItem.finalRubric: f. 70r Τέλος τοῦ λεξικοῦ τῶν Ἡροδοτείων λέξεων
msItem.note: Ff. 41r-41v are blank

msItem.title: Notes on Timaeus of Locri
msItem.incipit: f. 72r σ. 43 χο. 9 φύσιν, οἷον τὸ πῦρ κατὰ τὴν ἑαυτοῦ θερμότητα
msItem.explicit: f. 72r χο. 29 δευτέρᾳ περιόδῳ ἤτοι ἐμ δευτέρῳ βίῳ
msItem.note: The text consists of brief citations from the text (ed. W. Marg, The Pythagorean texts of the Hellenistic period (ed. H. Thesleff), Abo 1965, pp. 203, 205-225, TLG 1734.001; the attribution to Timaeus, of Locri Timaeus of Locri , is considered spurious), underlined, and brief explanatory comments; references are made to locations in the text (a printed edition?)

msItem.title: Notes on Plato's spurious works
msItem.incipit: f. 72v Περὶ δικαίου. Τά πολλὰ ψεύδονται ἀοιδοί
msItem.explicit: f. 73v τούτους δὴ τοὺς εἰς τὰ γένη τεταγμένους, γενήτας καλοῦσιν

msItem.title: Fragmenta et titulus
msItem.incipit: f. 73v Ἐπίτριτος τοῦ πράτου ὁ φιβ· ὑπερέχει γὰρ αὐτοῦ τοῖς ρκη
msItem.note: This is a fragment from a spurious work attributed to Timaeus of Locri Timaeus, of Locri
The text starts in the manuscript at W. Marg, The Pythagorean texts of the Hellenistic period, ed. H. Thesleff, Abo 1965, p. 211 l. 22

msItem.title: Four inscriptions
msItem.note: f. 76r is blank

msItem.title: Transcription of an inscription once in St James's Park, Westminster
msItem.incipit: f. 74v Ἡρώδης μνημεῖον καὶ τοῦτο εἶναι τῆς αὐτοῦ συμφορᾶς
msItem.explicit: f. 74v εἰς τὴν βουλὴν συγκλήτου δόγματι
msItem.note: A note in black ink specifies the provenance of the inscription, In hortis Divi Jacobi prope Westmonasterium

Regilla Herodis Attici uxor post a. 161, see G. Dittenberger, Sylloge Inscriptionum Graecarum, 2, Leipzig 19173 , 858; the inscription was on a stone originally found in Rome, and afterwards transferred to Britain, but now destroyed
Dittenberger 19173, 858; Prideaux Marm. Oxon. append. 302, 28; CIG 6185; Kaibel IG XIV 1392

msItem.title: Epitaph of Peter Young
msItem.incipit: f. 74v A Seton eq. aur. ser.mo ac pot.mo
msItem.explicit: f. 74v Obiit Ian. vii an. mdcxxviii aet. sae. lxxxiiii
msItem.note: The epitaph is dated in 1628

msItem.title: Transcription of a Latin inscription
msItem.incipit: f. 75r In his aedificis et locis puris adiacentibus
msItem.explicit: f. 75r quam sententiam sanctam esse omnes sciunto idque totum testatur marmor.
msItem.note: A note in black ink specifies Exstat inter inscriptiones Lipsii fol. 14 pag. b: the inscription has been published in M. Smet, Inscriptionum antiquarum quae passim per Europam, liber. Accessit Auctarium a Iusto Lipsio, Lugduni Batavorum 1588, fol. xiiii, no. 2; the inscription is located, in the edition, in Naples, in domo Hadriani Gulielmi

msItem.title: Transcription of a Latin inscription
msItem.incipit: f. 75v Ab colonia deducta anno xc N Fufiolo N.F.M. Deullio duo vir
msItem.note: A note in black ink specifies Exstat in Inscriptionibus antiquis Lipsii fol. 14: the inscription has been published in M. Smet, Inscriptionum antiquarum quae passim per Europam, liber. Accessit Auctarium a Iusto Lipsio, Lugduni Batavorum 1588, fol. xiiii, no. 1; the inscription is located, in the edition, in Naples, in domo Hadriani Gulielmi
The same hand which wrote the reference to Lipsius' work corrected in the right margin the faulty transcription of the names in ll. 2-3, Fufidio and Pullio

msItem.title: Transcription of a Latin funerary inscription
msItem.incipit: f. 75v Ossua Loadiceae Philadis hic sita sunt memoriae facti et infamiae
msItem.explicit: f. 75v tacito nomine extra sortem ad R. P.
msItem.note: See, slightly different, CIL, vol. vi, 5, *43
The inscription has been written directly after the preceding text; a horizontal line has been traced in order to separate them

support.material: ff. 1-76 Thick western paper, folded in folio. No watermarks are visible.
ff. [i]-[ii], [iii]-[v] Western paper, folded in folio. No watermarks are visible.

foliation.p: Modern foliation in pencil, in Arabic numerals, in the upper margin right from 1 to 76; there are 2 unnumbered modern endleaves at the beginning and 3 at the end of the manuscript: [i]-[ii] + 1-76 + [iii]-[v].

collation.p: The leaves have been sewn very tightly, there is no numbering of the quires, and there are no watermarks. It was not possible to determine the collation.

supportDesc.condition: The leaves have not been trimmed, therefore the edges are very worn and damaged, particularly at the beginning and at the end of the manuscript, where portions of the margins have been lost and repaired with Japanese paper. There are humidity and water stains throughout, as well as dirt stains.

layoutDesc.layout: No regular layout throughout. On ff. 49v-51r the text has been written transversally.

handNote.p: ff. 2r-4r, 71r, 72r Hand A: a minuscule script slightly slanting to the right, characterized by a generally round form of uprights, which generally end with ornamental tails and flourishings.
The text is written in black ink

ff. 4v-40v, 42r-43v, 66r-68r, 69r-70r Hand B: the texts have been written by Estienne, Henri, 1531-1598 Henri II Estienne (1531-1598) , in an informal minuscule, vertical (RGK II, 148, where ff. 4v-44v and 66r-68v are attributed to him; however, in my opinion, ff. 44r-44v are to be attributed to Patrick Young, see hand C, and ff. 66r-68v probably to Henry Scrimgeour, see hand D).
Titles and final rubrics throughout are written in a more "baroque" variant of the script, with a lot of ornamental flourishings (see e.g. f. 8v, ff. 12v-13r).
The text is written in a brown ink.
Estienne wrote also parts in Latin.

ff. 44r-44v, 49v-51r, 74v-75v, 76v, marginal notes on ff. 49v-51r, 70v, 72v-75r, 76v: hand C, Patrick Young (1584-1652) Young, Patrick, 1584-1652 , in a minuscule script, slightly slanting to the right, flowing, regular in size, characterised by contrast between thin and thick strokes and small flourishing tails at the end of some vertical and oblique strokes (see e.g. rho, csi, beta, zeta, eta). For the identification see M. R. James, The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College Cambridge, vol. 3, Cambridge 1902, p. 325, where the manuscript is said to have been written largely by Patrick Young; more precisely the hand of Young has been identified by P. Isepy 2020, p. 208 note 99, on ff. 49v-51r, 57r-63v, 70v, 72v-75r, 76v, marginal notes on ff. 2r, 66r-68r, 69r. The script on ff. 57r-63v and 72v-74r, however, in my opinion, is not that of Patrick Young: althought the script is contemporary and very similar, it is more rigid, upright, some characteristic features of Young's hand are missing, such as the characteristic beta, slanting to the right, and with an ornamental hook at the end of the upright, rho with the upright slanting to the left and ending with an ornamental hook, csi with a loop in the upper part, slanting to the left, and there are forms which are not present in Young's script, like the high tau in form of a 'flag', zeta in the form of a '2', without ornamental loops. For other examples of te script of Patrick Young, see, for example, London, British Library, Harley 7522 B ).
The text is written in a light brown ink.

handDesc.handNote: ff. 57r-63v, 72v-74r Hand D: a minuscule script similar to Patrick Young's, probably also by a western European hand, upright, rigid.

ff. 66r-68r The text in these leaves has been copied by hand E, Scrimger, Henry, 1506-1572 Henry Scrimgeour (1505-1572) (see James, p. 325; Isepy 2020, p. 208). On f. 66r, in the right margin, there is a note written by Patrick Young about the text on ff. 66r-68r, who defines the text inscriptio magni avunculi manu scripta: Scrimger was his great-uncle (under the note another hand specified Magnus avunculus... Scrimgerus Scott.. In RGK II, 148 the copying of these leaves has been assigned to Henri II Estienne; although the script is similar to his hand, some characteristic features are different.

decoDesc.decoNote: On ff. 4v-43v, where the text has been written by Henri II Estienne (hand B), there are small decorative elements near titles, very roughly traced, see e.g. ff. 16r, 19r, 42r) in red ink.

additions.p: On the left pastedown are written, in brown ink, the present shelfmark, O.5.23, and an older shelfmark relating to the Gale collection, A. 20.
On f. 1r there is a title in black ink, Thomas Reinusius in variis Lect. multa emendat. p. 425. 446 | Collectanea Varia.
On f. 1v there are notes in Greek and Latin by hand A, written probably at different times (they have been written in three different inks)

On f. 76v there are notes by Patrick Young:
A list of works in Greek
An extract from the catalogue of the library of S. Antonio di Castello in Venice: Ex catalogo Bibliothecae Sancti Antonii ; at the end, by another hand, In catalogo Bibliothecae S. Antonii, Venetiis, nulli ex his libris apparent. Quare Basilii Magni Grammatica exercitamenta Gesne.
In the upper, left, part of the leaf a note in a very faint ink is visible.

binding.p: Modern binding: paper cover over couched-laminate boards; parchment on spine, where are pasted three paper labels with the shelfmark O 5 23. 365 235 ca. 23

origin.p: The manuscript is probably a composite, formed by various parts, which were originally independent, and were copied at different times. The leaves containing texts copied by Henry II Estienne (1531-1598) and Henry Scrimegeour (1505?-1572) were copied in the 16th century; since some of the texts written by Estienne were copied from a manuscript of the convent of S Marco in Florence, and since the French scholar travelled to Italy (and was in Florence) in the years 1552-1555, the his portion of the manuscript could be dated around this time. The leaves transcribed by Patrick Young (1584-1652) were copied later, probably in the first half of the 17th century.

provenance.p: The manuscipt was owned by Gale, Thomas, 1635?-1702 Thomas Gale (1635/1636-1702) , Regius professor of Greek at the University of Cambridge, High Master of St Paul's School and Dean of York. It appears among Thomas Gale's Greek manuscripts in E. Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ, Oxoniæ 1697, p. 189, where it appears as 9 items: no. 5975 (141) Collectanea varia in Lucianum, no. 5976 (142) Astrampsychus de Somniis, no. 5977 (143) Variae Lectiones in Lucianum, no. 5978 (144) Decretum Marmoreum de Seleuco. Excerpta e Dionysio Atticista, no. 5979 (145) Lexicon Herodoti, no. 5980 (146) Argumenta orationum Isocratis, no. 5981 (147) Variae Lectiones ad Aristotelis Politica, no. 5982 (148) Aristotelis libri de Plantis, no. 5983 (149) Quaedam Notae in Euripidem, in folio.

history.acquisition:
It was donated to the Library by Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744
in 1738. On f. 1v is pasted the Trinity College bookplate. On ff. 1v, 68v, 69r, 70v, 76v there are stamps of Trinity College.

recordHist.source: Description (2020) draws partly on M. R. James, The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College Cambridge, vol. 3, Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 1902, p. 325.

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

monogr.title: The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College: a descriptive catalogue
The tradition of the minor Greek geographers

monogr.title: El copista griego Jacobo Diasorino (s. XVI): estudio paleográfico y codicológico de sus manuscritos

analytic.title: Towards a new text of Helladius. Neglected Manuscript Evidence on Photius’ Bibliotheke
